questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target cell: Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the postsplenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme..

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells: Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Lymphocytes in human circulating blood are approximately 80 to 90 percent T cells, and 10 to 20 percent B cells. The T-cell to B-cell ratio in the normal marrow varies between 4:1 and 5:1, and a significant increase in T-cell numbers was observed in reactive and myelodysplastic states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.

questions.text: During her pregnancy, the lady regularly cleans her cat's litter to prevent toxoplasma infection. What is the specific infective stage of this organism found in the cat feces? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oocysts

 

Oocysts are the infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii that are shed in the feces of infected cats. These oocysts are highly resistant and can survive in the environment for extended periods, becoming infectious to other hosts, including humans, once they sporulate. When a pregnant woman comes into contact with these oocysts, there is a risk of transmitting the infection to the fetus, which can lead to serious congenital abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradyzoites are the form of Toxoplasma that are found within tissue cysts in intermediate hosts.

 

Option B. Tissue cysts, containing bradyzoites, are found in intermediate hosts such as rodents and birds, and not in cat feces.

 

Option C. Tachyzoites are the rapidly multiplying form of the parasite that disseminates throughout the host's tissues during acute infection but are not the form found in cat feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii found in cat feces is the oocyst, which poses a risk of infection if ingested.

choices.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110 mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrombolysis

 

With a BP below 185/110 mmHg, clear NCCT, and symptoms within 4.5 hours, the patient qualifies for thrombolysis, the standard treatment for acute ischemic stroke to dissolve clots and restore blood flow.

 

If the blood pressure (BP) is more than or equal to 185/110 mmHg, administer IV labetalol to lower the BP to less than 185/110 mmHg before immediately proceeding with thrombolysis. CT angiography can be performed while thrombolysis is ongoing. Start the thrombolytic agent in the CT room and simultaneously inject a bolus of contrast for the CT angiogram to check for large vessel occlusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography: CT angiography can be done simultaneously with thrombolysis but not instead of it.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is not the immediate next step when NCCT is clear.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is used to lower BP but not the primary treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


In acute ischemic stroke with BP < 185/110 and clear NCCT, thrombolysis is the next step.

choices.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

 

Refsum's disease is a peroxisomal disorder caused by the impaired alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, which results in the buildup of phytanic acid in the body. This accumulation of phytanic acid is a characteristic feature of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Beta oxidation is a different metabolic process.

 

Option C. Omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Omega oxidation is a different metabolic pathway.

 

Option D. Alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids: Refsum's disease primarily involves the defect in the alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, not the alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:

 

  • No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • H2O2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:

1. α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)

2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)

 

Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.

  • Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

 

Most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma is Non-functioning adenoma

 

An adrenal incidentaloma is an unexpected adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease.

 

Non-functioning adrenal adenomas do not secrete hormones in significant amounts to cause clinical syndromes. They are benign tumors that are often discovered incidentally on imaging studies. Histologically, they are similar to hormone-secreting adenomas, but they do not produce clinical symptoms or biochemical abnormalities. They are the most common type of adrenal incidentaloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical Cushing's syndrome: Subclinical Cushing's syndrome refers to the mild or asymptomatic cortisol excess from an adrenal adenoma. These patients lack the full-blown signs and symptoms of overt Cushing's syndrome but might show subtle manifestations of cortisol excess or have abnormal laboratory findings.

 

Option B. Aldosterone producing adenoma: Aldosterone producing adenomas are a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism. They produce excess aldosterone leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. Patients may have suppressed renin levels in the blood due to feedback inhibition from the elevated aldosterone.

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce excessive amounts of catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine). Symptoms often include paroxysms of hypertension, headache, sweating, and palpitations. While these are serious tumors, they are a less common cause of adrenal incidentalomas.

choices.text: The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition
The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible
They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design
The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding suicidal inhibition? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition

 

SUICIDE INHIBTION

 

Suicide inhibition, also known as mechanism-based inhibition, is a unique and fascinating aspect of enzyme kinetics. It's a process where an enzyme binds to a substrate analogue, which initially seems like a normal substrate to the enzyme. However, as the enzyme starts to act on this 'pseudo-substrate,' a chemical reaction occurs that modifies the enzyme in such a way that it becomes irreversibly inactivated. This process is termed 'suicide' because the enzyme actively participates in its own inhibition.

 

STEPS INVOLVED IN SUICIDE INHIBITION

 

  1. Binding: The suicide substrate, which is often structurally similar to the actual substrate, binds to the enzyme's active site.
  2. Initial Reaction: The enzyme catalyses a reaction on this substrate analogue, similar to how it would act on its natural substrate.
  3. Formation of Reactive Intermediate: This reaction, however, leads to the formation of a chemically reactive intermediate. This intermediate is the key to the suicide inhibition mechanism.
  4. Modification of Enzyme: The reactive intermediate then reacts with the enzyme itself, leading to a covalent modification of the enzyme. This modification typically occurs at the active site, crucial for the enzyme's activity.
  5. Irreversible Inhibition: As a result of this modification, the enzyme is irreversibly inactivated. It can no longer bind to its natural substrate or catalyse the reaction it was designed for.
  6. Specificity: One of the key features of suicide inhibition is its specificity. Because the inhibitor is structurally similar to the natural substrate, the process is highly specific to the targeted enzyme. This makes suicide inhibitors very effective as drugs, as they can selectively target and inactivate specific enzymes in the body.

 

Other Options:

Option B. The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible: This is true. The substrate analogue binds irreversibly to the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Option C. They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design: This is true. Suicide inhibitors are designed to be highly specific for the target enzyme, making them valuable in rational drug design.

 

Option D. The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it: This is true. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of the substrate analogue to a reactive intermediate, which then irreversibly modifies the enzyme, leading to its inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLINICAL IMPORTANCE

 

Suicide inhibitors have significant implications in drug development, especially for designing drugs that target enzymes involved in disease processes. For instance, certain antibiotics work by suicide inhibition of bacterial enzymes, and some drugs used in the treatment of hypertension and depression also act through this mechanism.

 

Understanding the mechanism of suicide inhibition helps in the development of more effective and specific drugs, with fewer off-target effects. It's a powerful example of how knowledge of biochemistry can be applied in medicinal chemistry and pharmacology.

 

EXAMPLES OF SUICIDE INHIBITORS

 

  • Beta lactams (Penicillins)
  • Aspirin
  • Allopurinol
  • MAO inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following can be given for long term management of obesity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liraglutide

 

Liraglutide is an injectable medication originally developed to treat type 2 diabetes but has also been approved for weight management in obesity. It works by mimicking the hormone GLP-1, which regulates appetite and calorie intake. Liraglutide has been shown to be effective for long-term weight management and is considered a viable option for obesity treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metformin: While metformin is primarily used to treat type 2 diabetes, it has been observed to cause modest weight loss in some people. However, it is not primarily indicated for the treatment of obesity and is usually not the first choice solely for weight management.

 

Option C. Sibutramine: Sibutramine was previously used as an appetite suppressant for weight loss, but it has been withdrawn from the market in many countries due to cardiovascular safety concerns. Therefore, it is no longer recommended for obesity treatment.

 

Option D. Fenfluramine: Part of the fen-phen combination, fenfluramine was used for weight loss but was withdrawn from the market due to serious side effects, particularly heart valve issues. Like sibutramine, it is no longer considered safe or appropriate for obesity treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liraglutide is a viable and approved option for the long-term management of obesity. It works by mimicking the hormone GLP-1 to help regulate appetite and reduce calorie intake. Other Options like sibutramine and fenfluramine have been withdrawn from the market due to safety concerns, and metformin, while causing modest weight loss, is not primarily indicated for obesity treatment.

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers 

 

The given Box and Whisker plot depicts different types of data distributions:

 

  1. Normal distribution - The median is in the middle of the box, with whiskers of equal length.
  2. Positively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the bottom of the box, with a longer whisker on the upper end.
  3. Negatively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the top of the box, with a longer whisker on the lower end.
  4. Normal distribution with outliers - The median is in the middle of the box, with equal whisker lengths and the presence of outliers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and Whisker plot

 

  • A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

 

The auditory pathway is the sequence of neural structures that sound information travels through from the ear to the brain for processing. The correct sequence from the initial sensory input at the ear to the higher centers of the brain is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion : Contains the cell bodies of the auditory nerve fibers. These neurons receive mechanical sound vibrations converted into electrical signals by the hair cells of the cochlea.

 

1. Cochlear nucleus : The first brainstem nucleus where auditory nerve fibers synapse. This nucleus begins the central processing of auditory information.

 

3. Superior olivary nucleus : Receives inputs from both cochlear nuclei and is involved in binaural cues for sound localization.

 

4. Inferior colliculus : A midbrain nucleus that acts as a major relay and integration point for auditory information.

 

5. Medial geniculate body : Part of the thalamus that acts as the final relay station for auditory information being sent to the auditory cortex in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). 
    1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
    2. Cochlear Nucleus
    3. Superior Olivary nucleus
    4. Lateral lemniscus
    5. Inferior colliculus
    6. Medial geniculate body
    7. Auditory cortex
  • The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

The given set of instruments are commonly used for taking a Pap smear. The instruments include:

 

  • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix.
  • Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample.
  • Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample.
  • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively.
  • Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure involves using a hysteroscope to visualize the inside of the uterine cavity, and the instruments shown are not used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Biopsy: While some of these instruments might be used in a cervical biopsy, the specific combination shown is typically for a Pap smear.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure involves dilating the cervix and scraping the endometrial lining, which requires different instruments than those shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The set of instruments shown, including Cusco's speculum, Koplin's jar, slides, Ayer's spatula, endocervical brush, and fixative, are used for performing a Pap smear to collect and preserve cervical cell samples for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of action of vancomycin as shown in  the image below
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Vancomycin is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase. Therefore, in the above given image, it acts at the step 4. Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent used against gram positive bacteria.
 

Other options:


Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: It is inhibited by Cycloserine. It is a structural analog of D-alanine and inhibits the enzymes alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine and d-alanyl-d-alanine ligase, thereby preventing the incorporation of D-alanine into the peptidoglycan chain.

 

Option C. 3: Bacitracin inhibits step 3 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin acts at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, thereby inhibiting further elongation and cross-linking of the peptidoglycan.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region. It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.

 

The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII): The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.

 

Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma


Phacolytic glaucoma occurs when high intraocular pressure (IOP) is associated with a mature or hypermature cataract. The patient's right eye exhibits high IOP (50 mmHg), flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens, all of which are characteristic signs of phacolytic glaucoma. The leakage of lens material into the anterior chamber induces an inflammatory response, causing the observed clinical signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: This condition typically features a shallow or flat anterior chamber, which contrasts with the described deep anterior chamber. Therefore, it is not consistent with the clinical findings of this patient.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: This is usually a unilateral condition characterized by chronic inflammation, heterochromia (differences in iris color), and low-grade inflammation. It does not typically present with such high IOP or a cataractous lens as the primary issue.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: This type of glaucoma occurs due to lens-induced angle closure and is associated with a shallow anterior chamber. The patient, however, has a deep anterior chamber, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

choices.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes
Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts
Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys
Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys

questions.text: PTH increases Calcium in blood. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) primarily acts to increase the concentration of calcium in the blood. It achieves this through several mechanisms:

  1. Stimulation of osteoclasts to resorb bone, leading to the release of calcium from the bones.
  2. Increased absorption of calcium in the intestines.
  3. Stimulation of the kidneys to reabsorb more calcium, reducing its excretion in the urine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes: Osteocytes are embedded in the bone matrix and are not directly involved in the rapid release of calcium. Osteoclasts, on the other hand, are responsible for bone resorption.

 

Option B. Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts: Osteoclasts are indeed involved in the rapid release of calcium from bones. However, the complete action of PTH includes not only osteoclast activity but also increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys: While PTH does stimulate increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, the complete action also involves the rapid release of calcium from bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating calcium levels in the blood and the mechanisms by which it accomplishes this task.

 

  • Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range.
  • Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes:
    • Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream.
    • Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body.
    • Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.

questions.text:
A diabetic, hypertensive, and post-MI patient on atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin has lipid profile results of total cholesterol: 238 mg/dL, triglycerides: 125 mg/dL, HDL: 50 mg/dL, and LDL: 160 mg/dL. Which additional medications should be considered to optimize lipid management in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Bemepedoic acid
  2. Ezetimibe
  3. Gemfibrozil
  4. Evolocumab
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Explanation: 


The patient has elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol with normal triglycerides and HDL. Therefore, drugs targeting cholesterol reduction would be most appropriate:

 

1. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis

 

2. Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption

 

4. Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor) increases LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL clearance All these mechanisms would help lower the elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels.

 

Other Option: 
 

3. Gemfibrozil is incorrect as fibrates primarily target high triglycerides, which are normal in this patient (125 mg/dL).

 

Educational Objective: 
 

Lipid-lowering medications based on the specific lipid abnormality: statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, ezetimibe, and bempedoic acid for elevated cholesterol/LDL; fibrates primarily for elevated triglycerides.

choices.text: Decrease scavanging of RBC by macrophages

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease generation of reduced glutathione

 

G6PD deficiency results in reduced production of reduced glutathione (GSH), an important antioxidant in red blood cells. This decrease in GSH levels impairs the cell's ability to neutralize harmful reactive oxygen species (ROS) and, as a result, increases oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease membrane lipid peroxidation: G6PD deficiency can lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione levels, which normally help protect red blood cell membranes from oxidative damage. Therefore, a deficiency in G6PD can actually increase membrane lipid peroxidation, making red blood cells more susceptible to damage from oxidative stress.

 

Option C. Decrease NADH generation: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the production of NADPH (not NADH), which is essential for the regeneration of reduced glutathione and the maintenance of antioxidant defenses in red blood cells. NADPH is crucial in protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

 

Option D. Decrease scavenging of RBC by macrophages: G6PD deficiency can actually increase the susceptibility of red blood cells to phagocytosis by macrophages. The oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells caused by G6PD deficiency can lead to the removal of these damaged cells by macrophages, causing hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells).

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency is associated with a decrease in the generation of reduced glutathione , leading to increased oxidative stress and susceptibility of red blood cells to damage and hemolysis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 185-186

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Nocardia
  2. Mycobacterium leprae
  3. Actinomyces
  4. Cryptosporidium parvum
  5. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Cystoisospora belli (Options 1, 2, 4, and 5) are acid-fast staining organisms.

 

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Nelson are:

 

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

 

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Other Option

 

3. Actinomyces: Actinomyces is not an acid-fast organism. They are gram-positive bacteria that are known for forming filamentous structures similar to fungi but do not retain the acid-fast stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.

 

 

 

Y- chromosome 

 

The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.

 

Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

choices.text: IgA Tissue Transglutaminase antibodies are present
IgG deamidated Gliadin antibodies are present

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain, acute diarrhea, and is diagnosed with celiac disease. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Associated with HLA DQ6/DQ11

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. It is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. 

 

Associated with HLA DQ6/DQ11 because celiac disease is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8, not HLA DQ6/DQ11.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgA Tissue Transglutaminase antibodies are present: This statement is correct. The patients are going to be having the presence of IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies " These antibodies have high sensitivity and specificity for celiac disease diagnosis and are used as primary serological tests.

 

Option C. Marsh Criteria used for diagnosis: This statement is correct. " Modified MARSH criteria is useful for making a diagnosis." The Marsh criteria classify the histopathological findings in small intestinal biopsies, ranging from normal mucosa to complete villous atrophy.

 

Option D. IgG deamidated Gliadin antibodies are present: This statement is correct. " IgG deamidated gliadin antibodies are used in celiac disease diagnosis, especially in IgA-deficient patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DQ6/DQ11, and diagnosis involves IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies, deamidated gliadin antibodies, and application of the Marsh criteria.

 

Important disease associated with HLA

questions.text: DNA Methylation is not involved in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base pair excision

 

Base pair excision repair (BER) is a mechanism that corrects DNA damage involving small, non-helix-distorting base lesions. This process is initiated by DNA glycosylases that recognize and remove damaged bases, followed by endonuclease activity, DNA synthesis, and ligation. DNA methylation does not play a direct role in this repair pathway.

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis. Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

It is involved in mismatch repair but not in the base pair excision repair mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Roles of DNA Methylation:

 

Option A. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation is involved in chromatin remodeling by recruiting proteins such as methyl-CpG-binding domain proteins (MBDs) that interact with histone deacetylases (HDACs), leading to chromatin condensation and gene silencing.

 

Option B. Mismatch Repair: DNA methylation marks newly synthesized DNA strands during replication, aiding in the identification and repair of mismatches.

 

Option C. Gene Silencing: DNA methylation typically leads to gene silencing by preventing the binding of transcription factors and promoting the formation of a condensed chromatin structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not involved in the base pair excision repair mechanism. Instead, it plays significant roles in chromatin remodeling, mismatch repair, and gene silencing by modifying the DNA structure and influencing protein interactions and gene expression.

choices.text: It is exclusively given in the deltoid
Not given after 7 days of the 1st dose of the vaccine
If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.text: A physician is preparing to administer post-exposure prophylaxis for a patient who has been bitten by a potentially rabid animal. Which of the following statements about the administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is INCORRECT? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) It is exclusively given in the deltoid

 

  • Dose of Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIg): 20 IU/kg body weight
  • Dose of Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin (ERIg): 40 IU/kg body weight
  • RIg must be given as soon as possible
  • RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine
  • RIg must never be given Intravenously
  • Entire dose of RIg (or as much as possible) must be infiltrated around the wound(s) site(s).
  • Remaining dose, if any, must be given Intramuscularly in deltoid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Involved in DNA repair

 

Telomerase is not primarily involved in DNA repair. While telomere maintenance can influence genome stability and prevent end-to-end chromosome fusions, telomerase itself does not play a direct role in the classical DNA repair pathways such as base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, mismatch repair, or double-strand break repair.

 

Telomerase is a specialized enzyme that adds repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes (telomeres) in eukaryotic cells. Its primary function is to maintain the length and stability of chromosomes by compensating for the loss of DNA that occurs during cell division.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Telomeres are repetitive non-coding DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect them from degradation and prevent chromosomal fusion.
  • Telomerase activity declines with age, leading to the progressive shortening of telomeres and eventual cell senescence or apoptosis.
  • In many cancer cells, telomerase activity is upregulated, allowing these cells to bypass senescence and continue dividing indefinitely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Has reverse transcriptase activity: Telomerase contains an RNA component that serves as a template for adding telomeric repeats to the chromosome ends. The enzyme uses this RNA template to synthesize DNA, acting as a reverse transcriptase.

 

Option B. Present only in Eukaryotes: Telomerase is found only in eukaryotic cells because prokaryotic chromosomes are typically circular and do not have telomeres that require maintenance.

 

Option C. Maintains the chromosome length: Telomerase extends the telomeres, preventing their shortening during DNA replication and thus maintaining chromosome length and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity, present only in eukaryotes, and is crucial for maintaining chromosome length by adding telomeric repeats. It is not directly involved in DNA repair.

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of death in cold water drowning? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vagal inhibition

 

  • In cold water drowning cause of death is Cold shock response/ hydrocution / immersion syndrome.
  • It is a series of neurogenic cardio-respiratory responses caused by sudden immersion in cold water.
  • Death results from vagal inhibition of the heart, i.e., cardiac arrest occurring due to increased stimulation of the vagus nerve by
  • Sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx
  • Diving into the water in a manner that is suddenly strikes the abdomen
  • Sudden in-rush of cold water into the ears

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asphyxia: Common in other types of drowning but not the primary cause in cold water drowning.

 

Option B. Laryngeal spasm: Can contribute to asphyxia but is not the primary mechanism in cold water drowning.

 

Option D. Cardiac arrest: While cardiac arrest occurs, it is due to vagal inhibition, not directly from cold water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cold water drowning, the primary cause of death is vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest due to the sudden stimulation of the vagus nerve from cold water immersion.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate brought to the outpatient department is found to have bilateral conjunctivitis. Chest X-ray done showed lung infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the infection? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the likely cause of the infection in neonatal conjunctivitis.
  • The infection usually appears 1 week after birth and is transmitted from the mother's cervix or urethra during delivery.
  • Symptoms include edematous conjunctiva, watery discharge that later becomes purulent or bloody.
  • Diagnosis involves taking samples from both the conjunctiva and oropharynx and examining them for intracellular inclusion bodies.
  • Treatment involves administering erythromycin ethylsuccinate 50 mg/kg daily in four divided doses before feeds for 2-3 weeks.
  • If left untreated, associated systemic diseases such as chlamydial otitis and pneumonia may develop later.
  • Both parents must receive appropriate treatment for genital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilus influenzae: This bacterium can cause conjunctivitis but is less likely to present with systemic involvement like pneumonia in the context of neonatal infection.

 

Option C. Streptococcus: While capable of causing neonatal infections, Streptococcus species are more commonly associated with other forms of neonatal morbidity such as sepsis or meningitis, rather than conjunctivitis with pneumonia.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: It is known to cause respiratory infections in older children and adults but is an uncommon cause of neonatal conjunctivitis or pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal conjunctivitis typically presents during the first month of life and the age of the neonate is an important clue to the infection's etiology.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

 

Retinal detachment occurs when the sensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This separation can be due to a retinal break, known as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which is the most common type. In patients with high myopia, there is an increased risk of peripheral retinal degeneration, leading to retinal holes that can progress to retinal detachment. The presence of floaters and flashes is a key symptom indicating retinal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with sudden severe headache and neurological symptoms rather than visual symptoms like floaters.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: While this can cause floaters, it is more commonly associated with trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or vascular abnormalities rather than high myopia.

 

Option D. Branched retinal artery occlusion: This condition usually presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in part of the visual field rather than floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Pneumomediastinum

 

Hamman sign, also known as Hamman's mediastinal crunch, is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium in cases of pneumomediastinum. This sign is caused by air in the mediastinum, which is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity. The presence of air in this area leads to a characteristic sound as the heart beats, which can be heard on auscultation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. Clinical signs include guarding, rigidity, and air under the diaphragm visible on imaging. Hamman sign is not associated with pneumoperitoneum.

 

Option B. Pneumopericardium: This condition involves air within the pericardial cavity surrounding the heart. While it can cause similar auscultatory findings, it does not specifically present with Hamman sign.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition involves both air and fluid in the pleural space. A significant clinical finding here is straight-line dullness on percussion, not Hamman sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamman sign, or Hamman's crunch, is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumomediastinum, characterized by a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat due to the presence of air in the mediastinum.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

choices.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1
A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin
A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH): Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.

 

B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH): GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.

 

C. Growth Hormone (GH): GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.

 

D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1): IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.

 

The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

questions.text: In Decompression sickness, which one of the following is not seen? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemodilution

 

Decompression sickness (DCS) occurs when a rapid decrease in ambient pressure causes dissolved nitrogen to form bubbles in the tissues and blood vessels. When divers ascend too quickly from deep water, the dissolved nitrogen doesn't have time to be eliminated through normal respiration and forms bubbles in various body tissues.

 

These nitrogen bubbles cause vascular damage and endothelial injury, leading to several pathophysiological changes. One significant effect is capillary leak syndrome, where the plasma extravasates (leaks out of blood vessels into surrounding tissues). This extravasation of plasma causes hemoconcentration (increased concentration of blood cells) as the fluid component of blood leaves the vessels while the cellular components remain. 

 

This is precisely why hemodilution (the dilution of blood) is NOT seen in decompression sickness

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hearing loss: This is seen in decompression sickness. Nitrogen bubbles can damage the inner ear structures, leading to hearing impairment. The bubbles can affect the cochlea and vestibular apparatus, resulting in hearing loss and balance disturbances.

 

Option C. Thrombosis/Coagulopathy: This is seen in decompression sickness. The endothelial injury caused by nitrogen bubbles activates the coagulation cascade. Additionally, the hemoconcentration leads to stasis of blood flow (Virchow's triad: endothelial injury, stasis, and hypercoagulability), promoting thrombus formation.

 

Option D. Visual disturbances: This is seen in decompression sickness. Nitrogen bubbles can damage the retina or affect the rods and cones, leading to various visual impairments. Bubbles can also form in the cerebral circulation affecting visual pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decompression sickness causes hemoconcentration (not hemodilution) due to plasma extravasation resulting from vascular damage caused by nitrogen bubbles.

choices.text: Topically applied sulfonamide antibacterial
Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Opioid receptor agonist

questions.text: Dorzolamide is a: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

 

Dorzolamide is a topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It helps in decreasing the rate of formation of aqueous humor in the eye, therefore useful in the management of glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topically applied sulfonamide antibacterial agents include silver sulfadiazine, Mafenide acetate, sulfacetamide etc.

 

Option C. Second-Generation Sulfonylureas are oral antidiabetic agents which act via increasing sensitivity of the insulin receptors and stimulate the release of insulin from the pancreas. It is used to manage type-2 diabetes mellitus. It includes Glipizide, Glyburide etc.

 

Option D. Opioid receptor agonist is the class of drugs which bind to the opioid receptors in the body. It includes Morphine, Pethidine, Fentanyl etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dorzolamide is a topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humor, making it effective in the treatment of glaucoma. This distinguishes it from sulfonamide antibacterials, second-generation sulfonylureas, and opioid receptor agonists, which are used for different medical conditions.

questions.text:
A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has (11;14) positive. Which of the following markers should be done to confirm the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. CD10;
  2. CD 200;
  3. SOX11;
  4. Cyclin D1
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

t (11;14) creating CyclinD1-IgH fusion gene is seen in mantle cell lymphoma has its origin from naive B cell.

 

Mantle cell lymphoma:

 

  • Uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 8% of all NHL
  • Usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life
  • Male predominance
  • Tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers
  • More indolent, SOX11 variant that often presents with circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low Ki67 (<10%).

 

Features:

 

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon - lymphomatoid polyposis

 

Histology:

 

 

 

Immunophenotyping:

 

  1. High levels of cyclin D1
  2. CD19, CD20
  3. Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain)
  4. CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL.
  5. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Other Options:

 

  • CD10 (1): CD10 is a marker commonly associated with follicular lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not mantle cell lymphoma.
  • CD200 (2): CD200 is expressed in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and other B-cell lymphomas but is not a primary marker for mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with t(11;14) translocation, confirming the diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma requires testing for Cyclin D1 and SOX11 expression.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1132-1133

questions.text: Match the following poisons and their probable mechanism of action: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

A. Zinc chloride:

 

  • Mechanism: Irritant
  • Explanation: Zinc chloride is a chemical compound known to cause erosive esophagitis and irritation to the eyes and mucous membranes.

 

B. Chloral hydrate:

 

  • Mechanism: Stupefying (CNS depressant)
  • Explanation: Chloral hydrate is a central nervous system depressant used historically as a sedative and hypnotic agent.

 

C. Quinine:

 

  • Mechanism: Abortifacient
  • Explanation: Quinine has been used historically to induce abortion, although its use in this context is highly dangerous and not recommended.

 

D. Potassium carbonate:

 

  • Mechanism: Corrosive
  • Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe²⁺).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On US, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which results in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a key diagnostic feature of angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid mass that may be hypervascular and can show necrosis but does not characteristically contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Usually presents as a well-circumscribed, solid mass with a central scar, which is not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure without solid components, typically with very clear borders and no internal complexity or enhancement.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of keratoconus? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haab's striae  

 

Haab’s striae are not a feature of Keratoconus. Haab's striae are seen in buphthalmos where the intraocular pressure is raised and the eyeball is enlarged as a whole. The enlarged cornea is associated with tears in Descemet's membrane called Haab's striae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Munson's sign: Directly associated with keratoconus. It is observed when the patient looks down, causing the lower eyelid to bulge out due to the cone-shaped cornea.

 

Option C. Irregular Astigmatism: A hallmark of keratoconus, resulting from the irregular thinning and bulging of the cornea.

 

Option D. Scissoring Reflex: This is a characteristic finding in keratoconus observed during retinoscopy due to the irregular shape of the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following signs may be elicited in keratoconus –

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum: Humans (definitive host), Cyclops (first intermediate host), and Fish (second intermediate host).
  • Paragonimus westermani: Humans (definitive host), Snail (first intermediate host), Crayfish and Crab (second intermediate host).
  • Brugia malayi: Humans (definitive host), Mansonia mosquito (intermediate host).
  • Fasciola hepatica: Sheep and Humans (definitive hosts), Snail (first intermediate host), Aquatic vegetation (second intermediate host).

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lightning strike

 

The image shows fern-like patterns, known as Lichtenberg flowers or filigree burns, which are characteristic of lightening injury.

 

Filigree burns:

 

  • Also called Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers
  • They pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence, they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns
  • They are transient erythema which appears within a few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 – 48 hours if the person survives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electrocution: Electrocution typically causes electrical burns which are different from the filigree burns seen in lightning strikes. These burns are usually deep and may show entry and exit wounds.

 

Option C. Marbling: Marbling refers to a postmortem change where blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks on the skin, occurring due to decomposition and is not related to electrical injuries.

 

Option D. Trickling down of acid: Acid injuries typically cause chemical burns with distinct, often more severe damage to the skin and tissues, and do not produce the characteristic fern-like patterns seen in lightning strikes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filigree burns or Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic for lightning strikes and appear as superficial, fern-like patterns on the skin that fade within 24-48 hours.

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling eye movements. Its primary functions include:

 

  • Abduction: Moving the eyeball away from the midline of the body. The superior oblique helps in turning the eye outward.
  • Depression: Moving the eyeball downward. The superior oblique assists in looking down, especially when the eye is in an adducted position.
  • Intorsion: Rotating the top of the eye towards the nose. This is the action of rotating the eyeball towards the nose, which is an inward rotation.

 

These functions can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID," where:

 

  • Superior Oblique LID stands for Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression.

 

The superior oblique muscle does not perform adduction, which is moving the eyeball towards the midline of the body. This action is typically performed by the recti muscles, specifically the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

questions.text: Selenocysteine is present in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase

 

Option B. Glutathione peroxidase: Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that contains selenocysteine in its active site. It plays a vital role in protecting cells from oxidative damage by catalyzing the reduction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides using glutathione as a cofactor.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: Glutathione reductase is an enzyme involved in the reduction of oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to its reduced form (GSH). It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option C. Thioredoxin peroxidase: Thioredoxin peroxidase (also known as peroxiredoxins) is a group of thiol-containing proteins involved in breaking down hydrogen peroxide during oxidative stress. It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option D. Thioredoxin oxidase: Thioredoxin oxidase is not a known enzyme. There is an enzyme called thioredoxin reductase, which is involved in maintaining the redox state of thioredoxin, but it does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:
  1. Glutathione Peroxidase
  2. Thioredoxin Reductase
  3. Iodothyronine deiodinase
  • Codon for selenocysteine: UGA
  • This AA is formed by co–translational (during translation) modification (not by post-translational modification).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine Ca ratio > 0.15

 

Nutritional rickets is a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired bone mineralization and growth. The incorrect statement in the context of nutritional rickets is:

 

This is typically seen in primary hyperparathyroidism, not in secondary hyperparathyroidism like that seen in vitamin D deficiency or nutritional rickets. In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is usually low because of the body's attempt to conserve calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

The following points summarize the key biochemical features of nutritional rickets:

 

Option A. Normal Calcium: In many cases of nutritional rickets, serum calcium levels are normal or low-normal at the time of presentation due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which compensates for the low calcium by increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

Option B. Low Phosphate: Hypophosphatemia is common in rickets due to decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate and increased renal excretion.

 

Option D. High PTH: Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs as a response to hypocalcemia, leading to elevated PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. Elevated PTH, low phosphate, and normal calcium levels are typical biochemical findings in this condition.

choices.text: Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia
Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia
Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia: Endothelial cell dysfunction is another etiology. Injured or activated endothelial cells may produce less nitric oxide and may secrete substances that promote coagulation and vasopressor sensitivity.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia: Vasospasm has long been associated with preeclampsia. Systemic endothelial activation causes vasospasm, which elevates resistance to produce hypertension. With diminished blood flow because of maldistribution from vasospasm and interstitial leakage, ischemia of the surrounding tissues can cause necrosis, hemorrhage, and other end-organ disturbances.

 

Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:

 

Angiogenic Factors:

 

  • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased
    • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1)
    • Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • Factors that are decreased are
    • PlGF
    • PAPP-A
    • VEGF

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preeclampsia, the prostacyclin: thromboxane ratio is decreased due to increased thromboxane A2 and decreased prostacyclin (PGI2).

 

Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The patient's clinical features are strongly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45XO), a condition characterized by:

 

  • Widely spaced nipples: Shield chest appearance.
  • Webbed neck: Due to congenital lymphedema.
  • Tanner grade 1 breast development: Indicates no breast development.
  • Streak ovaries on ultrasound: Ovaries that are underdeveloped and nonfunctional.
  • Hormonal profile: Raised FSH and LH due to lack of negative feedback from the ovaries, and reduced estradiol indicating ovarian failure.

 

Other clinical features of Turner syndrome include short stature, primary amenorrhea, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies. The syndrome results in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallmann syndrome: It is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), not hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: 46XY karyotype with female external genitalia, well-developed breasts, absent axillary and pubic hair, and gonads are testes, not streak ovaries.

 

Option D. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome: Mullerian agenesis, where secondary sexual characters are present but the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina are absent. This syndrome does not present with webbed neck or widely spaced nipples.

 

Educational Objective:
